awd_titl_txt: Increasing Learning and Efficacy about Emerging Technologies through Transmedia Engagement by the Public in Science-in-Society Activities
awd_abstract_narration:
The range of contemporary "emerging" technologies with far-reaching implications for society (economic, social, ethical, etc.) is vast, encompassing such areas as bioengineering, robotics and artificial intelligence, genetics, neuro and cognitive sciences, and synthetic biology. The pace of development of these technologies is in full gear, where the need for public understanding, engagement and active participation in decision-making is great. The primary goal of this four-year project is to create, distribute and study a set of three integrated activities that involve current and enduring science-in-society themes, building on these themes as first presented in Mary Shelley's novel, Frankenstein, which will be celebrating in 2018 the 200th anniversary of its publication in 1818. The three public deliverables are: 1) an online digital museum with active co-creation and curation of its content by the public; 2) activities kits for table-top programming; and 3) a set of Making activities.  The project will also produce professional development deliverables: workshops and associated materials to increase practitioners' capacity to engage multiple and diverse publics in science-in-society issues.  The initiative is funded by the Advancing Informal STEM Learning (AISL) program, which seeks to advance new approaches to, and evidence-based understanding of, the design and development of STEM learning in informal environments. This includes providing multiple pathways for broadening access to and engagement in STEM learning experiences, advancing innovative research on and assessment of STEM learning in informal environments, and developing understandings of deeper learning by participants.

This project by Arizona State University and their museum and library collaborators around the country will examine the hypothesis that exposing publics to opportunities for interactive, creative, and extensive engagement within an integrated transmedia environment will foster their interest in science, technology, engineering and mathematics (STEM), develop their 21st century skills with digital tools, and increase their understanding, ability, and feelings of efficacy around issues in science-in-society.  These three distinct yet interlocking modes of interaction provide opportunities for qualitative and quantitative, mixed-methods research on the potential of transmedia environments to increase the ability of publics to work individually and collectively to become interested in and involved with science-in-society issues.

por.por_cntn:
Frankenstein200 was a national research project led by Arizona State University and funded by the National Science Foundation that used Mary Shelley?s classic tale of creation and responsibility as a lens to examine emerging technologies such as artificial intelligence, synthetic biology, robotics, and human enhancement, and foster interest in science, technology, engineering, and mathematics (STEM) for learners in informal settings.

The project was built on three distinct elements:

  • A set of hand-on activities for museums, science centers, community centers, and other learning hubs that supported creative making activities related to electricity, robotics, artificial intelligence, and synthetic biology.
  • An original digital narrative that paired real-life collection objects from a broad range of museums with interactive storytelling tools (videos, web pages, puzzles, and games) to bring the themes of Mary Shelley?s Frankenstein to a new generation of learners and their families.
  • A set of at-home maker activities using common household items paired with online challenges and competitions to encourage the development of 21st century skills related to creative collaboration and critical thinking.

These elements, whether explored individually or in tandem with one another, were designed to prompt reflection on three questions that inform contemporary discussions about science, technology, and society:

  • What is life?
  • What does it mean to be human?
  • Why do we create?

Over the first two years of the project, the three elements were conceptualized, tested, refined, and fabricated in parallel with one another. Contributing partners included The Bakken Museum in Minnesota, The Rosenbach in Pennsylvania, the Museum of Science, Boston in Massachusetts, and No Mimes Media in California.

In 2017, the project team worked with the National Informal Science Education Network to identify and partner with museums around the nation that could present the hands-on activities kit to their patrons. Physical kits with materials for several hundred visitors were awarded to 51 museums in 35 states around the nation, and staff from these institutions were trained on these materials at in-person and virtual sessions. The materials and teaching resources were also offered online, at no charge, on the National Informal Science Education Network website: nisenet.org/frankenstein.

In January 2018, to commemorate the 200th anniversary of the publication of Frankenstein, the project was formally launched. Over the course of the year, researchers from the project team observed, measured, and analyzed data from 13 museum sites, participant behavior in the online narrative, and responses to the hands-on activities to measure how engaging in one or more of these activities affected the participants? notions of self-efficacy around scientific concepts and science ethics.

As this project featured three distinct elements, the research team also conducted studies in classrooms to observe the ways that these elements could be experienced in different sequences and configurations.

This research showed significant improvements to participants? science self-efficacy scores after completing the project?s activities, but there were no additional benefits for those who completed both the hands-on activities and online narrative. In addition, our observations showed that using Frankenstein as a ?hook? to talk about science and ethics was successful in engaging intergenerational audiences with these topics, validating previous findings regarding the benefits of narrative in in informal learning spaces and suggesting promise for interventions that apply narratives to STEM learning.

Expanding on these findings, the project team adapted the media, tools, and facilitation principles of Frankenstein200 to design interventions for learners at either end of the educational spectrum. In 2019, the team created lessons for preschoolers to learn about robotics. Through facilitation, students were asked to imagine robots that can fly, cook, stomp, dance, hug, and assemble themselves into a variety of configurations. Results were shared with scholars and practitioners in a Science and Children publication.

Also in 2019, the project team created in-person lessons and role-playing scenarios to help pre-service teachers in the May Lou Fulton Teacher?s college develop knowledge and confidence to take the lead in discussing science-in-society topics.

In late 2019 and 2020, the hands-on activities were further adapted to a series of coding and making activities and lesson plans to be utilized at afterschool and STEM clubs.

As a whole, the project validates the importance of synthesizing knowledge and methods across the humanities, social sciences,  and STEM fields. By grounding this work in a compelling popular narrative, and engaging our audiences in conversations that were both technically grounded in emerging technologies and ethically grounded in the stakes of scientific creativity and responsibility, we were able to foster a sense of efficacy and engagement with these important topics. Combining science, imagination, and storytelling has proven to be an effective model for engaging diverse audiences in the important question of how we understand the role of science in society.

This project has supported graduate students, a postdoctoral scholar, teachers-in-residence and has resulted in 12 conference and journal publications.
